citation: Weigelt, P., Daniel Kissling, W., Kisel, Y., Fritz, S.A., Karger, D.N., Kessler, M., Lehtonen, S., Svenning, J.-C., Kreft, H., 2015. Global patterns and drivers of phylogenetic structure in island floras. Scientific Reports 5, 12213. https://doi.org/10.1038/srep12213

generalAnnotations.summary: Authors test general mechanisms that lead to the formation of plant assemblages on a global scale. They found the ecological factors have more influence in shaping plant communities than dispersal limitations do. Importance of community shaping factors vary between major groups of plants
generalAnnotations.evaluation: It's a useful paper that would be good to keep in mind as tries to explain in a very broad scale the mechanisms that originate plant assemblages. The article is worth considering when comparing this global scope to more local scenario as closely related island groups at a finer scale.

usages: investigating processes that shape species assemblages
investigating the effects of abiotic island characteristics related to dispersal, environmental filtering and speciation on the phylogenetic structure
justifications: Quantifying phylogenteic assemblage structure allows inferences about species assemblages processes
links between patterns of plant diversity  and environmental variables are well documented but not much understanding of the underlying process
phylogenetic information can be used to infer assembly processes
objectives: Link phylogenetic assemblage structure to island characteristics worldwide
test dispersal filtering vs environmental filtering
shed light on th origin of insular plant diversity
investigating the effects of abiotic island characteristics related to dispersal, environmental filtering and speciation on the phylogenetic structure
hypotheses: (group differences): global patterns and determinants of phylogenetic structure vary among taxonomic groups due to differences in their dispersal ability, climatic adaptations, distribution patterns and diversification rates
(dispersal filtering): phylogenetic diversity and overdispersion increase with factors that facilitate dispersal to islands (e.g. low island isolation)
(environmental filtering) phylogenetic diversity and overdispersion are higher if island environmental conditions fit bioclimatic requirements of a clade (e.g. tropical climate for palms)
(in-situ speciation): factors that increase the probability of speciation on islands (e.g. larger islands area) are negatively related to phylogenetic overdispersion
expectations: If dispersal-related traits show a strong phylogenetic signal(i.e. closely related species share similar dispersal abilities, then dispersal filtering should lead to phylogenetically clustered island assemblages
generals: Environmental heterogeneity and past and present climate have been identified as key drivers of species richness on islands
remarks: A large amount of variation in phylogenetic structure of island floras can be explained by physical and bioclimatic island characteristics
drivers of phylogenetic structure have strong group-specific components, which supports the group differences hypothesis
environmental filtering plays a strong part on the phylogenetic structure of island floras
phylogenetically conserved physiologcal constraints of each group determine which factors act as environmental filters
methods: phylogenetic diversity  using Faith's PD (sum of all branch lengths representing the species of an island in a clade's pylogeny
degree of phylogenetic clustering vs. overdispersion ('i.e. higher vs. lower relatedness than expected by chance, measured as standardized effect size of mean pairwise phylogenetic distances (MPD)
comparison between major plant clades (angiosperms, ferns, palms)
dated family-level phylogeny for angiosperms and on dated genus-level phylogenies for palms and ferns
null models randomly shuffling all included species at the tips of the trees

citation: Carvajal‐Endara, S., Hendry, A.P., Emery, N.C., Davies, T.J., 2017. Habitat filtering not dispersal limitation shapes oceanic island floras: species assembly of the Galápagos archipelago. Ecology Letters 20, 495–504. https://doi.org/10.1111/ele.12753
remarks: Ability to detect climate signal despite limitations of climatic data available suggests that environmental filtering is strong
Habitat filtering  rather than dispersal limitation was likely the predominant process structuring plant species composition
Larger islands show phylogenetic overdispersion as a result of environmenal filtering, as larger islands harbours multiple habitats
expectations: If dispersal were the primary process shaping island phylogenetic structure, it is expected that more isolated islands to show greater phylogenetic clustering (assuming phylogenetic conservatism of dispersal traits).
if dispersal was more important, the presence of species on the archipelago should be best explained by their ability to disperse across long distances
objectives: Evaluates association of phylogenetic structure with its potential drivers
generals: Phylogenetic clustering could be driven by island isolation, speciation and/or strong environmental filtering by a habitat type on phylogenetically conserved traits; whereas phylogenetic overdispersion could result from competitive exclusion of closely related species, filtering across multiple habitats on an island, and/or environmental filtering for a single habitat type when key traits are convergent in the phylogeny
